entry.title: Integrando Podcasts a Kiu: Cómo Construí un Agente Virtual Serverless con AWS Bedrock y Pinecone
entry.summary:
Introducción
Tuve la oportunidad de unirme al equipo de Kiu, un proyecto innovador que permite conocer charlas, meetups y eventos de la comunidad AWS. Descubrí Kiu en el AWS Community Day Chile 2024 y me fascinó desde el primer momento. En febrero, Hazel Saenz me invitó a participar en el equipo. Mi primera tarea fue integrar contenido de podcasts dentro de Kiu, creando un subagente virtual capaz de consultar y procesar esta información para responder preguntas de forma precisa y eficiente. En este blog compartiré cómo diseñé y desplegué una infraestructura serverless robusta usando AWS CDK en Python, integrando Pinecone para búsquedas vectoriales y Amazon Bedrock para inteligencia artificial. Además, te contaré los desafíos técnicos que enfrenté y cómo los superé para entregar una soluc…

entry.title: 🚀 Mastering select_for_update() in Django: Prevent Race Conditions the Right Way
entry.summary:
Handling concurrency in your Django applications? Then you’ll want to make friends with select_for_update(). This handy ORM method helps lock database rows during a transaction, ensuring that your data stays consistent—even under high load. Let’s break it down with a real-world use case. 🔍 What Is select_for_update()? It’s especially useful for: Inventory systems Bank transfers Purchasing Ticket Preventing double submission 🛒 Example: Locking a Product Row During Checkout Here’s how to use select_for_update(): from django.db import transaction from .models import Product
def purchase_product(product_id, quantity): with transaction.atomic(): product = Product.objects.select_for_update().get(id=product_id)
if product.stock >= quantity: product.stock -= quantity product.save() return True else: return False
What’s happening here? We start a transaction using transaction.atomic(). We lock the product row with select_for_update(). The row stays locked until the block exits. ⚙️ Advanced Usage Product.objects.select_for_update(nowait=True).get(id=product_id)
nowait=True: raises an error if the row is already locked.
skip_locked=True: skips locked rows entirely (useful for task queues).
🧠 Final Thoughts select_for_update() wisely. Want to take your Django database handling to the next level? Start by locking smarter. 🔒 💬 Got questions or use cases? Drop them in the comments—let’s nerd out about transactions and Django internals.

entry.title: Unified Cloud & Shell Automation with pygcli
entry.summary:
Pygcli
pygcli is a versatile command-line toolkit designed to seamlessly unify Linux shell commands, Google Cloud operations, and Python workflows — all through a single, intuitive NPM package. Whether you're scripting automation tasks, interacting with cloud storage, or running Python scripts with arguments, pygcli bridges the gap between development and operations. Developers can execute familiar Linux commands directly from Node.js, upload files to Google Cloud Storage with ease, and trigger Python scripts as part of integrated workflows. Run Linux shell commands from Node.js Upload files to Google Cloud Storage Trigger Python scripts with arguments npm install -g pygcli
pygcli shell "ls -la" pygcli upload ./file.txt your-bucket-name pygcli python script.py arg1 arg2
node examples/s…

entry.title: nFolyo MVP Postmortem - What We Learned Building a Portfolio Tracker
entry.summary: Originally published at nfolyo blog We do not learn from experience… we learn from reflecting on experience. — John Dewey nFolyo is a portfolio tracking and analysis tool built for long-term investors like us — with global portfolios invested across equities and ETFs, not just limited to US and EU markets. It started as a collection of Python scripts and spreadsheets we used to manage our own portfolios. Over time, it evolved into a full-featured tool and became our learning ground for modern web development and microservice architectures. We released our MVP in November 2024 after eight months of intense development. After iterating on early user feedback, we released version 0.4.0 in March 2025 with several improvements. Now, we're at a turning point that requires us to rethink our appro…

entry.title: Why Developers Should Learn Linux (Even Just a Little)
entry.summary:
A lot of devs think Linux is only for backend people. Or sysadmins. Or those scary DevOps folks who live in Vim and wear black hoodies. But here’s the truth: If you write code, ship software, or debug anything in production — learning Linux will save your life at least once. Let’s talk about why. Even if you develop on Windows or macOS, your app is probably going to run on a Linux server, container, or cloud instance. If you don’t understand how Linux works, you’re flying blind in production. Ever watched a senior dev move faster with five terminal commands than a junior clicking through four GUIs? It’s not magic. It’s just Linux basics: grep, find, awk, sed
Navigating logs Killing processes Monitoring memory/CPU usage Small things. Big unlock. Your app works locally? Cool.
It crashes on…

entry.title: How to Use React to Build a Web Project – A Beginner’s Guide
entry.summary: React is one of the most powerful tools for building modern web applications. Created by Facebook, it helps developers build fast, dynamic, and responsive user interfaces. If you’re just starting out with web development or looking to explore something new, React is a great place to begin. The beauty of React lies in its component-based structure. You build small, reusable parts of the UI called components. These components can be combined and reused throughout your app, making development faster and your code easier to maintain. To start working with React, the first step is to install Node.js and npm (Node Package Manager) on your system. These tools help you manage your project’s dependencies and run your development server. Once installed, you can set up a new React project using a too…

entry.title: How to Use React to Build a Web Project – A Beginner-Friendly Guide
entry.summary:
React has become one of the most popular JavaScript libraries for building interactive user interfaces. Whether you're designing a simple to-do list or a full-stack application, React makes UI development easier, faster, and more scalable. In this guide, we’ll walk through how to set up a React project from scratch and build a basic app to understand its core concepts. 💡 What is React? 🔧 Prerequisites Before You Start Node.js and npm installed Basic knowledge of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript A code editor like VS Code 🛠️ Step 1: Setting Up Your React Project Run the following command in your terminal: bash bash bash http://localhost:3000. 🧱 Step 2: Understanding the Project Structure perl jsx function App() { Hello, React World! This is your first component! export default App; 🔄 Step 4: Adding State and Interactivity jsx function App() { return ( Counter: {count} 🎨 Step 5: Styling Your App Inline styles CSS files (like App.css) CSS frameworks like Tailwind CSS or Bootstrap Example using App.css: css jsx This is a Header Component ; }
export default Header; jsx function App() { Welcome to modular React! bash Netlify Vercel GitHub Pages 🔚 Final Thoughts Ready to take it further? Learn about: React Router for navigation Context API or Redux for state management React Query or SWR for API integration 📌 Keywords for SEO getting started with ReactJS React tutorial for beginners create-react-app tutorial building a web project with React

entry.title: React Server Components: The Future of Full Stack React
entry.summary: Hey fellow developers! 👋 Remember when we used to argue about whether to use Create React App or Next.js? Well, buckle up because React Server Components (RSCs) are about to change everything we know about building React applications. I've been experimenting with RSCs for the past few months, and honestly? I'm both excited and slightly terrified by how much they're going to reshape our development workflow. Let me share what I've learned and why I think this is the biggest shift in React since hooks. Imagine if your React components could run on the server, fetch data directly from your database, and send fully rendered HTML to the browser - all while still being interactive where it matters. That's essentially what React Server Components do. But here's the kicker: they're not replacing …

entry.title: How AI Is Transforming Legal Education in Law Schools
entry.summary: AI is making its mark not just in law firms—but also in law schools, where it's becoming a powerful tool for helping students learn faster, write better, and prepare for real-world legal practice. Smarter Legal Writing and Research: Law students are now using AI-powered platforms like Lexis+ AI, Westlaw Precision, and Casetext CoCounsel to assist with case law research, brief drafting, and citation formatting. These tools don’t just provide sources—they help students understand legal reasoning faster by offering plain-language explanations and suggestions. AI as a Personal Legal Tutor: Some professors and schools are integrating AI chatbots like ChatGPT to help students refine arguments, practice exam questions, and get real-time feedback on their reasoning. It’s like having a virtual TA on call 24/7. Enhanced Classroom Learning: AI tools can generate hypothetical cases, simulate negotiations, or assist in moot court prep. Instructors are also using generative AI to personalize content, quiz prep, and course materials. With law firms increasingly relying on AI, students are learning to use these tools early—so they’re practice-ready from day one. Knowing how to collaborate with AI is becoming a core skill, not just a tech bonus. AI is becoming an essential companion in legal education. By integrating these tools into their learning process, students are gaining a head start on the tech-driven future of law—building confidence, efficiency, and a modern skill set before they even step into practice. Created By: Dalton Breshears
